{| id="toc" border="0" ! {{MediaWiki:Toc}}: |[[#1969â70|1969â70]] â [[#1970â71|1970â71]] â [[#1971â72|1971â72]] â [[#1972â73|1972â73]] â [[#1973â74|1973â74]] â [[#1974â75|1974â75]] â [[#1975â76|1975â76]] â [[#1976â77|1976â77]] â [[#1977â78|1977â78]] â [[#1978â79|1978â79]] |} __NOTOC__ ==1969â70== {{NCAATeamSeason |Mode=Basketball |Year=1969â70 |Prev year=1968â69 |Next year= 1970â71 |Team=Maryland Terrapins |Image = |Conference=Atlantic Coast Conference |Division= |ShortConference= ACC |CoachRank= Not ranked |APRank= Not ranked |Record= 13â13 |ConfRecord= 5â9 |HeadCoach=[[Lefty Driesell]] |AsstCoach1= |AsstCoach2= |AsstCoach3= |StadiumArena=[[Cole Field House]] |Champion= |BowlTourney= |BowlTourneyResult= }} The year 1969 was a turning point in Washington sports history. The [[University of Maryland, College Park|University of Maryland]] had hired [[Lefty Driesell]] to coach basketball. The Senators named [[Ted Williams]] as manager. The [[Washington Redskins]] hired [[Vince Lombardi]] as Head Coach and he had brought a winning attitude to the nation's capital. It marked a renaissance in sports interest in America's most transient of cities. ===Team Players drafted into the NBA=== {|class="wikitable" width="80%" |- align="center" style="background:red;color:white;" | '''Round''' || '''Pick''' || '''Player''' || '''NBA Club''' |- align="center" bgcolor="" | 9||151 || Will Hetzel|| [[Washington Wizards|Baltimore Bullets]] |Next year= 1972â73 |Team=Maryland Terrapins |Image = |Conference=Atlantic Coast Conference |Division= |ShortConference= ACC |CoachRank= 11 |APRank= 14 |Record= 27â5 |ConfRecord= 8â4 |HeadCoach=[[Lefty Driesell]] |AsstCoach1= |AsstCoach2= |AsstCoach3= |StadiumArena=[[Cole Field House]] |Champion= NIT Champions |BowlTourney=[[1972 National Invitation Tournament|1972 NIT]] |BowlTourneyResult= [[1972 National Invitation Tournament|Champions]] }} Lefty Driesell started the tradition of [[Midnight Madness (basketball)|Midnight Madness]]in 1971 with an unofficial session that was attended by 3,000 fans at the [[University of Maryland, College Park|University of Maryland]]'s football stadium, [[Byrd Stadium]].<ref name=NMMfUUbt>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/college/basketball/la-sp-madness17-2008oct17,0,3319514.story|title=No 'Midnight Madness' for UCLA, USC basketball teams|accessdate=2008-11-30|date=2008-10-17|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|author=Pucin, Diane}}</ref><ref name=LmrsatM>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/s/2000/1011/812806.html |title=Lefty's midnight run started all the Madness|accessdate=2008-11-30|date=2007-10-13|publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures|work=[[ESPN.com]]|author=Rovell, Darren |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080326190934/http://espn.go.com/ncb/s/2000/1011/812806.html |archivedate = 2008-03-26}}</ref>
===National Invitation Tournament=== *First Round **Maryland 67, St. Josephs 55 *Second Round **Maryland 71, Syracuse 65 *Semifinal **Maryland 91, Jacksonville 77 *Final **Maryland 100, Niagara 69<ref>http://www.nit.org/history/nit-postseason-results-1970s.html</ref> ===Awards and honors=== * Tom McMillen, NIT Most Valuable Player * Tom McMillen, First Team All ACC<ref>http://www.sportsstats.com/bball/awards/All-ACC</ref> * Tom McMillen, Third Team All-American<ref>http://www.sportsstats.com/bball/national/awards/All-American</ref> ==1972â73== {{NCAATeamSeason |Mode=Basketball |Year=1972â73 |Prev year=1971â72 |Next year= 1973â74 |Team=Maryland Terrapins |Image = |Conference=Atlantic Coast Conference |Division= |ShortConference= ACC |CoachRank= 10 |APRank= 8 |Record= 23â7 |ConfRecord= 7â5 |HeadCoach=[[Lefty Driesell]] |AsstCoach1= |AsstCoach2= |AsstCoach3= |StadiumArena=[[Cole Field House]] |Champion= |BowlTourney=[[1973 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|NCAA Men's Division I Tournament]] |BowlTourneyResult= [[1973 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|Elite Eight]] }} In the offseason, Tom McMillen was a member of the [[United States men's national basketball team|US national team]] that took part in [[Basketball at the 1972 Summer Olympics]].
===NCAA Basketball Tournament=== *East **Maryland 91, Syracuse 75 **Providence 103, Maryland 89<ref>http://www.databasesports.com/ncaab/tourney.htm?yr=1973</ref> ===Awards and honors=== * Tom McMillen, Second Team All-American<ref>http://www.sportsstats.com/bball/national/awards/All-American</ref> * Tom McMillen, First Team All ACC<ref>http://www.sportsstats.com/bball/awards/All-ACC</ref> ===Team Players drafted into the NBA=== {|class="wikitable" width="80%" |- align="center" style="background:red;color:white;" | '''Round''' || '''Pick''' || '''Player''' || '''NBA Club''' |- align="center" bgcolor="" | 3||37 || Jim OâBrien|| [[Cleveland Cavaliers]] |- align="center" bgcolor="" | 10||155 || Bob Bodell|| [[Seattle SuperSonics]] |- align="center" bgcolor="" | 14||186 || Howard White|| [[Washington Wizards|Capitol Bullets]] |}<ref>http://www.databasebasketball.com/draft/draftyear.htm?lg=N&yr=1973</ref>
==1973â74== {{NCAATeamSeason |Mode=Basketball |Year=1973â74 |Prev year=1972â73 |Next year= 1974â75 |Team=Maryland Terrapins |Image = |Conference=Atlantic Coast Conference |Division= |ShortConference= ACC |CoachRank= 4 |APRank= 4 |Record= 23â5 |ConfRecord= 9â3 |HeadCoach=[[Lefty Driesell]] |AsstCoach1= |AsstCoach2= |AsstCoach3= |StadiumArena=[[Cole Field House]] |Champion= |BowlTourney= |BowlTourneyResult= }} Maryland participated in the ACC Final. The Final pitted two of the top teams in the country. It has been regarded by many to be the greatest ACC game in history â and one of the greatest college games ever. The game was instrumental in forcing the expansion of the [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship]] to 32 teams, allowing more than one bid from a conference. Maryland had six future NBA draft picks on the team. The six picks were Tom McMillen and Bob Bodell (1974)<ref>http://www.databasebasketball.com/draft/draftyear.htm?lg=N&yr=1974</ref>, Tom Roy and Owen Brown (1975)<ref>http://www.databasebasketball.com/draft/draftyear.htm?lg=N&yr=1975</ref> and John Lucas and Mo Howard (1976)<ref>http://www.databasebasketball.com/draft/draftyear.htm?lg=N&yr=1976</ref>. It is considered the greatest team that did not participate in the NCAA tournament.<ref name="free">Bill Free â [http://umterps.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/022199aab.html This Overtime Lasts 25 Years] The 1974 team left it all out on the floor. Baltimore Sun, hosted at University of Maryland Terrapins athletic site, February 20, 1999</ref>
===ACC Tournament=== The '''1974 [[Atlantic Coast Conference Men's Basketball Tournament]]''' was held in [[Greensboro, North Carolina]] at the [[Greensboro Coliseum]] from March 7â9. [[NC State Wolfpack men's basketball|North Carolina State]] defeated Maryland 103â100 in overtime 103â100 to claim the championship. *Quarterfinals (March 7): Maryland 85, Duke 66 *Semifinals (March 8): Maryland 105, North Carolina 85 *Finals (March 9): [[1973â74 NC State Wolfpack men's basketball team|NC State]] 103, Maryland 100 ===Awards and honors=== * Lefty Driesell, [[NCAA Award of Valor]]<ref name=recipients>[http://www.ncaa.org/wps/portal/!ut/p/kcxml/04_Sj9SPykssy0xPLMnMz0vM0Y_QjzKLN4j3CQXJgFjGpvqRqCKO6AI-YRARXwN9X4_83FR9b_0A_YLc0NCIckdFALOxkFY!/delta/base64xml/L3dJdyEvUUd3QndNQSEvNElVRS82XzBfTFU!?CONTENT_URL=http://www.ncaa.org/awards/honors_program/valor/winners.html NCAA Award of Valor recipients]</ref> * Len Elmore, First Team All ACC * Len Elmore, Second Team All-American * John Lucas, First Team All ACC<ref>http://www.sportsstats.com/bball/awards/All-ACC</ref> * John Lucas, Second Team All-American * Tom McMillen, Second Team All-American<ref>http://www.sportsstats.com/bball/national/awards/All-American</ref> ===Team Players drafted into the NBA=== {|class="wikitable" width="80%" |- align="center" style="background:red;color:white;" | '''Round''' || '''Pick''' || '''Player''' || '''NBA Club''' |- align="center" bgcolor="" | 1||9 || [[Tom McMillen]]|| [[1974-75 Buffalo Braves season|Buffalo Braves]] |- align="center" bgcolor="" | 1||13 || [[Len Elmore]] || [[1974-75 Washington Bullets season|Washington Bullets]] |}<ref>http://www.databasebasketball.com/draft/draftyear.htm?lg=N&yr=1974</ref>
